ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Connection weight mutation schemes
ygData.msgSnippet: ... umm, I think this discussion probably belongs on alt.philosophy :) ... Yes except that [in SharpNEAT anyway] old species are discarded if there are other

X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Ian Badcoe wrote:

>
>A-ha!!!
>
>You just inspired me to understand an issue which has been at the back of 
>my mind for quite a while but I was never quite able to put into clear 
>words.  I think this is quite an important concept.
>
>It's the difference between mortals and immortals.
>  
>
umm, I think this discussion probably belongs on alt.philosophy :)

>(e.g. in a system with an "elite" the "elite" are immortal, they live many 
>generations)
>  
>
Yes except that [in SharpNEAT anyway] old species are discarded if there 
are other equally fit species around. They're immortal for a while anyway :)

>There's two different types of fitness involved.  Call them "immediate 
>fitness" and "iterated fitness".
>
>Immortals must have immediate fitness, they have to successfully compete 
>with the rest of the population so their individual fitness must be high 
>for whatever day-to-day tasks the population is tested against.  An 
>immortal can have defective reproduction machinery without impairing this 
>immediate fitness.  As long as it continues to measure up against the rest 
>of the population it can hang around forever...  Looked at another way, 
>99.9999% of its children may be still-born, but it can afford to wait for 
>the one in a million.
>
>Mortals, in contrast have to have iterated fitness.  A mortal with 
>defective reproduction machinery is only a transient phenomenon and will 
>not be in the next generation.
>  
>
Resisting the urge to make some bad jokes at this point, but yes I'm 
with you...

>Thus they evolve under quite different pressures.  In systems without any 
>"meta-parameters" in the genes (like plain NEAT) there is little or nothing 
>the differential pressure can act upon.  Because there is nothing which 
>_can_ change the individuals ability to have children.
>  
>
I think this is probably true of 'plain' NEAT as it stands, but if you 
have a modular genome then some modules may be more able bind with other 
modules beneficially, so the evolution has a sort of sub-thread of 
evolving modules that not only perform well at the immediate task, but 
that also combine well with other modules. You end up with a  sort of 
co-evolution of modules and symbiotic relationships being set up.

>ES, on the other hand, has its degree-of-mutation parameters (mutabilities, 
>"strategy variables") and these have the effect, as Colin pointed out, of 
>changing the (immediate) fitness of not the individual, but its 
>children.  This is (in my terminology) changing the iterated fitness.  Thus 
>the definition of "iterated fitness" is something like:
>  
>
>IF[1](who) = sum(child in children(who) : Fitness(child) * 
>relatedness(child, who))
>
>IF[n](who) = sum(child in children(who) : IF[n-1](child) * 
>relatedness(child, who))
>  
>
Ok yeh, so IF is something we can only calculate for an individual 
several generations after he/she/it came about, and will tend to be a 
large number for an individual that is an ancestor of a large number 
modern day individuals.

>[[relatedness of parent and child is 1/2 (with equal probability crossover) 
>and parent and grand-child is 1/4...]]
>
>As you see, it varies according to how many generations you look ahead 
>(e.g. the current-day IF of any T-Rex is zero...) and is an emergent 
>property only visible after the event.
>  
>
As a side not I'd just like to say that T-Rex as a species (particular 
combination of genes) is dead, but most of those genes are still around 
today in modern day species, including homo-sapiens.  So T-Rex will 
score zero, but if we focus in on individual genes we get a different 
picture. In fact, finding genes that have a high IF in nature will tend 
to identify very old genes that encode for fundamental structures such 
as cells, bone, organs, etc. Actually the highest scores will go to any 
genes that made it into modern day insects, on account of their large 
numbers.

>So in ES without an elite ("comma strategy" they call it) we are breeding 
>not only for the ability to solve the problem presented, but also for the 
>_ability_ to breed solutions to the problem.
>  
>
I don't think keeping an elite is entirely incompatible with breeding an 
ability to generate good solutions. Some elite might rarely spawn good 
solutions, but that might be a better solution than any found by the 
masses, because they could propogate by evolving the same mediocre 
solutions over and over.

>Which is what closes the loop and allows the mutability parameters to 
>evolve to useful values in parallel with the functional genes.  Whether 
>they contribute to the search is a different question...
>  
>
It closes the loop but I'm still concerned about the large amount of 
drift that might occur in the meta genes. If you have identified an 
optimal set of meta-parameters then a NEAT search will progress more 
efficiently using that set of fixed params than if we allowed a search 
to continually drift around the search space.

>--
>
>Another point about this is that it is closely tied to mutual fertility 
>between two individuals.  e.g. if two individuals are crossed over, 
>depending on the compatibility between their genomes, then the offspring 
>may be of similar fitness to the parents or else greatly reduced in 
>fitness.  This is down to issues akin to the "competing conventions" problem.
>  
>
A problem currently solved with historical markers and speciation, we 
already have some parameters in this area that could be optimised 
(speciation threshold and the three coefficients), but maybe we could 
parameterize the compatibility function further - and therefore allow 
individuals to effectively decide who they are compatible with (and 
therefore who they wish to mate with) to a greater degree then they do now.

>Now, if there is no crossover, then there is no drive for the individuals 
>to remain mutually fertile.  On the other hand, even if there is crossover, 
>an immortal individual may have little drive to be fertile with the bulk of 
>the population.
>
Ok but we kill the elite off eventually, and we define a species culling 
age to determine how long we are prepared to wait for an elite species 
to spawn off new better genomes.

>  Conversely, if the elite breeds with the non-elite, and if 
>the elite father a largish proportion of the children, then the non-elite 
>may be held back needing to remain compatible with the elite.
>  
>
Speciation currently prevents this sort of situation from occuring, but 
it's interesting to think about the kind of dynamicas that might be set 
up if we allow evolution more of a free reign. I can definitely see 
that  an elite individual or species might propagate itself by mating 
with other species to generate very poor offspring, thus keeping the 
original elite alive and the population as a whole supressed. So yeh, 
maintaining elite individuals at the same time as evolving meta-genes is 
probably a bad idea.



>--
>
>Another (vaguer) point is the difference between merely passing time and 
>passing generations.  e.g. if we don't have an elite, then each individual 
>lives one generation but during that generation gets only one chance to 
>breed (or to be exact, once chance to breed a few times).  The reason this 
>may matter is that, in nature, individuals frequently take note of their 
>own breeding success when deciding whether to breed more.  e.g.
>
>(1) to some extent a bonded pair will keep having sex _until_ the female 
>gets pregnant -- so any (minor) incompatibilities between them (which might 
>kill the offspring in the womb) get overridden by persisting until they get 
>lucky (without spewing out hundreds of offspring whether they get lucky or 
>not).
>  
>
It's a good point, I think it would be extreme to only allow one round 
of mating before an individual dies, although a number of biological 
species use this model, so it's probably not that bad. So we could allow 
individuals to stick around until they reach some pre-defined 'death' 
age. This complicates how we keep the population down to a reasonable 
level, in nature the population of successful species tends increase as 
far as resources allow - our resources are very limited inside a 
computer. I guess we just keep culling the weakest individuals to trim 
the population back to a reasonable number as we do now.

>(3) in some species individuals pick a different partner each year, thei 
>enables them to exploit (1) within the year but switch to somebody else in 
>case they turn out completely infertile
>  
>
This ensures a good mix-up of the gene pool. Again, resisting urge to 
crack bad jokes :)

>Food for thought...
>
>  
>
Interesting stuff,

Colin.
